results.title: Ex-President Sarkozy Convicted for Campaign Spending Violations
results.abstract: Nicolas Sarkozy was found guilty of illegally financing his 2012 presidential bid by exceeding France’s strict electoral rules and sentenced to a year of house arrest. He said he would appeal.

multimedia.caption: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy of France on Wednesday in Madrid.
Former President Nicolas Sarkozy of France on Wednesday in Madrid.

results.title: After Knife Attack, New Zealand Criminalizes Terror Plotting
results.abstract: A law passed Thursday makes planning a terrorist attack a crime, addressing a legal loophole weeks after an ISIS sympathizer stabbed people at a supermarket.

multimedia.caption: The police standing outside the site of a knife attack at a supermarket in Auckland, New Zealand, earlier this month.

results.title: Police Officer Sentenced to Life in Prison for Murder of Sarah Everard
results.abstract: Ms. Everard’s killing this year inspired a national call to action in Britain to address violence against women. The court heard this week how Wayne Couzens used his police ID and handcuffs in abducting her.

multimedia.caption: Outside the top criminal court on the second day of the sentencing hearing in London on Thursday. Harrowing details about the crime were publicly revealed on Wednesday.

results.title: Police Storm Ecuador Prison Where More Than 100 Inmates Died
results.abstract: The officers entered the prison after two days in which gangs connected to criminal drug cartels battled for dominance inside the prison system.

results.title: Amid Tensions With U.S., Erdogan Praises Ties With Russia
results.abstract: Meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said “there is no path back” from Turkish-Russian military deals opposed by the West.
results.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Carlotta Gall

results.abstract: The General Assembly speeches exalted the ideals of the United Nations but showed intransigence on many longstanding disputes and armed conflicts, some nearly as old as the organization itself.

results.title: U.K. Labour Leader Makes a Firm Push to the Political Center
results.abstract: Speaking at the party’s annual conference, sometimes over heckling, the Labour Party leader, Keir Starmer, signaled a clear break from the former leader, Jeremy Corbyn.

results.title: German Police Arrest 96-Year-Old Nazi Suspect Who Tried to Skip Court
results.abstract: The woman, a former secretary in a concentration camp in Poland now facing more than 11,000 counts of accessory to murder, failed to show up for a court appearance on Thursday.

results.title: Japan’s Likely Next Prime Minister Tries to Set Himself Apart
results.abstract: Though Fumio Kishida, a ruling-party stalwart, has sought to distinguish himself from the unpopular departing prime minister, he’s struggled to connect with the public.

multimedia.caption: Fumio Kishida at the headquarters of the Liberal Democratic Party. Next month, when Japan’s Parliament holds a special session to select the next prime minister, his appointment is essentially guaranteed.

results.title: Gas Shortages Awaken Britain to Some Crucial Workers: Truck Drivers
results.abstract: Dwindling pay, poor roadside conditions and post-Brexit immigration rules have led to a critical shortage of drivers. Despite appeals, some say they are reluctant to return.
results.byline: By Eshe Nelson and Megan Specia

multimedia.caption: A truck stop on a highway in Grantham, England. Dirty showers, not enough toilets and a lack of security at some roadside stops have made the job less attractive, some drivers said.

results.abstract: The magazine caused an outcry last year after it published a fictional narrative depicting the legislator as an enslaved African.

results.title: Daintree Forest in Australia Is Returned to Indigenous Owners
results.abstract: The rainforest is among nearly 400,000 acres of land in northeast Australia that were handed back on Wednesday to Aboriginal people who have lived in the region for thousands of years.

results.abstract: The authorities told residents of the Spanish island to keep their windows shut, warning of powerful chemical reactions as molten rock meets seawater.

results.title: In Paris, It’s Literary Scandal Season Again
results.abstract: The Goncourt prize, a standard-bearer of the French novel known for its probity, has come under criticism over charges of conflict of interest after a juror voted to include her partner’s novel in a list of contenders.
results.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut

multimedia.caption: Pierre Assouline, Philippe Claudel, Patrick Rambaud, Pascal Bruckner, Didier Decoin, Camille Laurens, Francoise Chandernagor, Eric-Emmanuel Schmitt and Tahar Ben Jelloun before a Goncourt judges meeting last year at the Drouant restaurant in Paris.

results.title: Reduced to Rubble, an Afghan Village Struggles to Rebuild
results.abstract: A small village outside Ghazni found itself on a critical supply artery in war-torn Afghanistan. It paid a heavy price.

results.title: Sarah Everard Was Falsely Arrested by Her Murderer, Court Hears
results.abstract: Wayne Couzens, a British police officer who pleaded guilty to the murder of Sarah Everard, used the pretense of Covid regulations to kidnap the 33-year-old as she was walking home.

multimedia.caption: The police moving to disperse a vigil for Sarah Everard in London in March. Harrowing details of the killing were laid out publicly for the first time in a sentencing hearing on Wednesday.

results.title: Tunisian President Appoints Prime Minister Amid Protests Over Power Grab
results.abstract: President Kais Saied named Najla Bouden Romdhan, the country’s first female prime minister. But it may do little to dispel fears he is moving toward one-man rule of the nation where the Arab Spring began.

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Najla Bouden Romdhan, left, meeting with President Kais Saied. She is Tunisia’s first female head of government.

results.abstract: The move ends a long period of uncertainty for a Sri Lankan family that hosted the National Security Agency contractor in their tiny apartment in 2013.
